Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of the Low-Lying Nuclear Isomeric Transition in the A = 229 Isotope of Thorium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support the PI and his group in bringing the techniques of laser physics to a nuclear system with the goal to directly detect and characterize a unique excited state in the A = 229 isotope of thorium. The state is a low lying excited state that is now able to be investigated with current laser technology. The ultimate goal is to use the characteristics of that state to investigate one of the most compelling questions in modern science: Are the constants of nature actually constants? Further, two technological applications with significant impact have also been proposed: a nuclear clock, which could outperform all current and planned optical clocks, thereby improving navigation and communication, and a gamma ray laser in the optical range.


Under this award, the PI and his group will perform a direct search for this nuclear transition to better measure the transition energy and lifetime in order to enable the aforementioned promising applications. Specifically, they will interrogate thorium-229 atoms, which have been doped into a vacuum ultraviolet transparent host crystal, with a laser system capable of directly exciting the nuclear state. The resulting nuclear fluorescence will be monitored to determine the transition energy and lifetime. Once the transition is found, the potential of the transition for use as a clock oscillator will be explored by comparing a preliminary thorium clock architecture to more established atomic clocks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over four decades ago, the existence of a low-lying state in the nucleus of the A = 229 isotope was was indirectly established through measurements of gamma-ray energies resulting from alpha decay of uranium. Recently, this state has been confirmed and with an energy of ~ 8 eV. Although well into the vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) region, this energy is, by far, the lowest for any known nuclear transition and, most importantly, is still amenable to study by laser spectroscopy.

Broadly speaking, the ability to drive a nuclear transition with a narrowband, coherent laser could be groundbreaking. As this would bring the techniques of atomic physics to bear on a nuclear system, it is anticipated that this approach will yield full quantum control of the nuclear degree of freedom and with it a number of important scientific and technogical advances. These include two technological applications with significant impact: a nuclear clock, which could outperform all current and planned optical clocks and potentially revolutionize navigation and communication, and a gamma ray laser in the optical range.

Further, it is expected that a precision measurement of the thorium isomeric transition frequency could answer one of the most compelling questions in modern physics: Are the constants of nature actually constants? Recent astrophysical measurements have claimed observation of fundamental constant variation over cosmological space-time scales. Moreover, current theories that attempt to unify gravity with the other fundamental forces can lead to spatial and temporal variations in the fundamental constants, e.g. the fine structure constant . Thus, sensitive probes for possible variation of fundamental constants provide an important means to constrain these models, which are clearly extensions to the Standard Model.

Given the fundamental nature and importance of the problem of constant variation, there has been an enormous amount of work to search for variation in the fundamental constants. Historically, this work fell into two categories: astrophysical measurements, which probed potential constant variation over cosmological time scales, and terrestrial measurements, which were much more precise, but typically studied the value of a constant for only a few years. Until recently, the two thrusts of research had little overlap. Astrophysicists claimed that the constants – e.g.  – were smaller in the past by about 10 parts per million over ~10 Gyr, while lab-based measurements claimed that the constants were indeed constant within experimental error of about 1 part in 1017. It was thought that perhaps the constants were different in the past, but have now “settled.” Most people working in the field thought that the discrepancy would never be resolved since the precision lab-based measurements could never probe the early universe. However, in 2011, astrophysicists compiled their data and concluded that it also predicted a spatial variation of  in the universe. Because our galaxy is moving, this astrophysical data predicts that  is now changing by 1 part per 1019 every year.

            Unfortunately, a variation in  at this level is not detectable with current lab based measurements, which are limited to precisions worse than  – due to, among other things, fluctuations in the local gravitational field. The nuclear isomeric transition in thorium-229 appears to offer a solution to this problem. Because interactions in the nucleus occur at the MeV energy scale, as opposed to the eV scale in atomic measurements, a nuclear energy level is roughly  times more sensitive to any variation in the fundamental constants. Thus, it has been shown that a measurement of the thorium isomeric transition over only one year could limit the variability of  to much better than 1 part in . Therefore, if the nuclear isomeric transition in the thorium-229 can be found, it should be possible to either conclusively rule out or confirm the astrophysical data. By directly measuring the thorium-229 isomeric transition, we will enable an entirely new direction of research: laser-based control of the nucleus.

Thus, the intellectual merit of this project is to enable a host of new opportunities for controlling and studying atomic nuclei, and work towards definitively answering the question of whether or not the fundamental constants are varying. As such this project could usher in a new era in technology (broader impacts) by providing a robust, portable frequency reference which can be used for improved navigation, time keeping, and jamming resistant communication.

Through this project a variety of advances were made. First, a vacuum ultraviolet laser was constructed and used to constrain the energy and lifetime of the excited nuclear state. Second, a super-conducting nanowire device was employed to perform a preliminary measurement of the excited nuclear state internal conversion lifetime. This technique holds promise for a measurement of the nuclear excited state energy and is the subject of future work.
